position.marginalia_text: Catonis versus adamantini, et profundi. Quâ flumen placidum est, forsan latet altiùs vnda. Et, Tuta magè est puppis, modito qua[e] flumine fertut.

marginalia.translation: The verse of the incorruptible and profound Cato. "Perchance the quiet rivers too deep run." And, "safest the ships which smallest waters ply." [trans. Wayland Johnson Chase, 1922]

position.marginalia_text: Et, Fistula dulce canit, volucrem dum decipit auceps. Et, Ne sis ventosus, dum vis vrbanus haberi. Et, Quod potes, id tenta: nam littus caarpere remis Tutius est multò, quàm velis tendere in altum. Et, Vulnera dum sanas, dolor est Medicina doloris. Et, Vitandum ducas, inimicum nomen amici.
Et, Fronte capillata, post est Occasio calua. Et, Cognita iudicio constant; incognita Casu.

marginalia.translation: And, "Sweet sounds the fowler's pipe to lure the prey". And, "Lest thus thou fail to be what thou wouldst witty seem". And, "Begin what thou to finish canst not fail. Safer near shore than on the deep to sail". And, "To cure the hurt thy grief will well suffice". And, "Lest false to thee, thy fame and goods he spend." And, "Behind Time's bald, his forehead's thick with hair". And, "ried friends are sure, untried may not be so." [trans. Wayland Johnson Chase, 1922]

position.marginalia_text: Cum Venere, et Baccho Lis est, et iuncta Voluptas: Quod lautum est, animo complectere, sed fuge Litem. Sic in rebus omnibus, excerpendum est, quod inest boni: fugiendu[m], quod adha[e]ret Mali.

X-ref.text: Cum Venere, et Baccho Lis est, et iuncta Voluptas: Quod lautum est, animo complectere, sed fuge Litem.

marginalia.translation: "With love and wine pleasure and strife are knit; Cleave to the good in these; the bad omit." [trans. Wayland Johnson Chase, 1922] Thus in all matters, one must select what belongs to good things: one must avoid what is involved in bad things.

position.marginalia_text: Eutrapelus voluit esse candidissima mundi anima: nulli odiosus: cuiq[ue] indulgens, quotiès vlla gratificandi occasio; sine suo damno. Etiam cum propria res contra ageretur, valdè dulcis: vtcunq[ue] in fine, et in effectu suus. Pars beneficij est, quod petitur, benè neges.

X-ref.text: Pars beneficij est, quod petitur, benè neges

marginalia.translation: Eutrapelus wished to be the polished mind of the world; annoying to no one and pleasant to everyone, as often as any occasion for gratifying; without his condemnation. Even if he would act against his own person, [he would be] truly delightful: as however himself in goal and in effect. "To refuse gracefully is to confer a favour" [trans. Stone, 2005].
